values: Briefly, business is going well and I just got some really nice high end items on consignment from an advanced collector friend of mine. I'm typically hesitant about consignment deals, but we've worked out a good deal, and I get to work with some juicy pieces, including a mark and period Jiaqing bowl, possibly imperial. In all the tumult, however, I try to take time to stop and smell the....lichens?
http://ibis-news.livejournal.com/5202.html

Some of the things I'm working with or have sold recently: From an acquaintance in Singapore, I found this Chinese plate from the first quarter of the 19th century. It was made for export to SE Asia. This big monochrome rouleau vase was made circa 1890, in what we would call the tail end of the Kangxi Revival, when lots of 17th century styles were en vogue. With incised sea dragon design. Peacock turquoise blue with fish roe crackle glaze. I love this color. This bowl bears a Qianlong mark in overglaze iron red...but it is spurious. In reality, this piece is typical of Tongzhi (about 1860) heavily potted minyao (common, peoples) wares, but of better quality than most. This ware has become something of a specialty of mine. Not many people are aware of it. Late 19th century, prunus design on a yellow ground, glazed on the biscuit. Lidded jars are not really my thing, but in this case the melon shape is completed only with the stem on the top of the lid.
http://ibis-news.livejournal.com/4942.html

The days fall into weeks, fall into months, and I find myself here for the first time in some time. 
Quick recap, perhaps details to follow:

My move to Trocadero is still looking like a good decision: selling things! 
Trip to L.A. for a seminar on ancient metallurgy at UCLA/Getty, hosted by Prof. David Scott; got me thinking of grad school in conservation.....

No forge work lately....antiques have been keeping me busy. 

pics to follow
http://ibis-news.livejournal.com/4660.html

Ah, its been a while. I'm still here, and have been selling swords and porcelain. 
I suppose the biggest development recently is that I've recently joined Trocadero.com and am trying to build my listed inventory there. Its a much higher quality place than ebay...much better for my purposes for now. But a thing I've learned and observed is that to work in this business, one must have many ways of selling items. For instance, Ebay, Trocadero, a store, a live auction, space in antique malls, a website. Many of the successful dealers I know are represented in all of these. In any event, I'll endeavor to write a bit more. I'll leave with posting this image of a 2nd century Gandharan grey schist sculpture of the head of Buddha. I've just posted this on my trocadero site.
http://ibis-news.livejournal.com/4369.html

Sometimes when I've been going over the same problem in my head for too long, the most constructive thing I can do is ride or lift. 


Spent the evening clearing my mind on the Lake Jackson Prairie.  



Gems of piquancy

ate some of these


These were tasty too

More where they came from   


Lots more. Hundreds of acres.



This one seems appropriate these days...



There was water here..                                                                                      
 

Not so much now.


You can't see very much if you are 6 inches tall, and hop around.                             


But to compensate, you can make this. Lotus pod not included


A lone dead tree. The ground around it is scattered with the bones of snakes and small mammals.  And the ever present shotshells.  Apparently some raptors enjoy lunching there. 


Yup, tree.


Chariot in the background.
 

Little bones. Also there was a snake skeleton, and some pieces of gar fish skulls.
   

So many small lovely things in this wide space

Not edible.                                     
 

From the foot of the lone dead tree, looking up. My favorite pic from this trip.


No lions or zebras, but sometimes I wonder...


water hyacinth
      









Time to head home with this bit of light left.
http://ibis-news.livejournal.com/4309.html
Made a little every day carry knife. Feels good in the hand. Six inches overall. Split a hog knuckle bone and wrapped it on each side of the grip.
http://ibis-news.livejournal.com/3921.html

A visit to Monkey Creek: 



Begins with a beautiful Spider Lily




Continues through pine, wiregrass, and palmetto scrub.




Which opens to another world.




The water is very low, we're having quite a drought.




A Chinese literatus would find infinite inspiration here.


Hell, anyone would be hard pressed not to.



Remember to click on the pics for a larger view






Here is JF, who appears to be speaking into a small silver something while consoling a well-behaved woodland animal who nearly stepped on a Copperhead, one of the more poisonous snakes on the continent. I didn't get a photo of the snake because JF and I ran into it while we were slinking single file, skirting the water's edge along a steep sandy slope. The suspicious sunning serpent separated us from forward progress until a serious JF, in the lead, cajoled it with a soft stick until it silently slid inside a cypress stump.
http://ibis-news.livejournal.com/3806.html

Old technology isn't necessarily appealing because it is romantic, or delightfully anachronistic. Often, old tools that are not used anymore are much more pleasant to use. 

I put together this pump drill recently, along with this little wooden mallet. They were fun to make and didn't take long.  The pump drill is about 18 inches tall, the mallet is about 15.  The drill is almost silent, and the mallet works great for hitting smaller things that might be damaged by a metal hammer.
http://ibis-news.livejournal.com/3439.html

I've been doing a lot of trail riding lately on my bike. Tallahassee may not be the most cosmopolitan place, but it does have some lovely woods. A week ago I discovered a small pond out near Lake Jackson, the once 4000 acre lake north of Tallahassee which was swallowed up by a sinkhole a few years ago. A few days ago I strapped some gear on, jumped on the bike, and rode out to do a little flyfishing. 

This is the road you take. A decade ago this was all about 10 feet under water. 



This is the spot I was fishing from. You can see the gator path leading to the water down in the bottom right corner. Luckily it was a small one, more interested in the Gar fish than me.




Another shot of the tranquil Florida wetland. This was taken right before a wild turkey exploded from the underbrush next to me, nearly toppling me into the water.
http://ibis-news.livejournal.com/3139.html

Also, more work was done today on Jesse's bread oven. Its nearly ready! Pics to come.

So I'm getting the hang of the new photography setup, and while my pics aren't yet where I'd like them to be, they are getting damned close. I'll put some up soon, as I'm auctioning some really beautiful things this week. 
In the mean time, here are two photos from an old surplus junkyard outside of Quincy called Parramores, run by the amiable and sly Mr. Hootie.
http://ibis-news.livejournal.com/2759.html

The business has been slow for a few weeks while I've been setting up a new computer system and upgrading my photo setup. Things are coming together on both those fronts now, so I should be able to get back to selling. 

I've been busy otherwise, as well. Perhaps most exciting is the large bread oven I've been helping to construct. Pics to follow soon. 
I have done a little with blades lately. 

Here are views of a blade I made some time ago, newly modified, and with a sheath that I just made for it. Impromptu pics, but they came out ok. You can click to make them larger.


I've really got smelting and wootz on my mind. Time to get cookin.
http://ibis-news.livejournal.com/2425.html

An update on the business- items are moving, things are good. Here are some items I'm selling:

A 19th century Piha Khaetta dagger, the national dagger of Sri Lanka. about 12" long


Showa period (circa 1920) Japanese monochrome vase, Awaji ware. about 8" tall


19th century Japanese small vase, underglaze blue maybe Arita or Hirado? about 4" high


19th century Chinese bowl. Iron red enamel of lucky bats, foliage, shippo design. Rubberstamped mark to the foot in archaic zuanzhu rather than the typical kaishu script, probably tongzhi circa 1860. about 5" across

Well, I'm rushing again to meet some deadlines for my business. Sometimes I really wish the internet would close at 5 oclock.

Some more inventory came in recently, some really good stuff. I'll post pictures as I take them.
However, here is a Japanese piece I picked up at a big show near Orlando a month ago:



Sort of a nice piece I think. Signed on the foot in underglaze blue, but I'll need to consult the members of the Gotheborg forum if I hope to get a translation.

Also, I've been thinking more about timberframing and the like.
Somewhat frustratingly, my business cards and stamp still aren't ready. I'll have to call again tomorrow.
http://ibis-news.livejournal.com/1445.html

So I'm not making so many knives right now. Jesse has reached a point where he needs a more professional dedicated shop building on his property. Thats a major goal of his for now, and I'm very excited to be helping to realize it.  It's pretty great, because I'm being introduced to traditional building methods and tools and other fun stuff.  I'm helping to: fell trees, bark them, split them, turn them into timbers and lumber , and eventually carve joints into them and put them all together. 

I came across a neat method of setting foundations. A company called Pin Foundations makes these concrete things that sit on the ground, to which you can anchor timbers to. Pipes are drived through it into the ground, at an angle, and they serve to hold everything down.

They look like this. Imagine that darker grey band represents ground level.

With the mold-making skills I gathered from working at FSU's Master Craftsman Program, I'm sure it would be pretty easy to build some molds to make some similar things.
But we are still working on site preparation! Its amazing how persistent grape vines can be.  I would never have guessed how difficult it could be to clear a 40' x 60' or so area.

Today, one of the interesting things we did was cut a cat-face. Around the turn of the last century, throughout the region turpentiners catfaced pine trees to collect the sap. As you might guess, this resin was processed into turpentine and sold nationwide. We are doing exactly what they did, but instead of making turpentine, we'll be making varnishes, sealants, glues, and other things. These are cat-faces:





Oh, and here is a little Chinese piece I found:



Its a cute little sancai (three colors) biscuit glazed brush washer or something similar. About 3 inches across. Nice colors. Circa 1890 I should think.
I think I need to make a little polishing station in my place. Many of the blades that come in would sell for more if I could polish and etch them to some extent. Something to think about
http://ibis-news.livejournal.com/1149.html

I wanted to post a photograph of an ornamental iron project I did some months ago. I've very little experience forging this type of thing, and the project turned out pretty well for such a rookie attempt. Below is one of four pairs, each is about 10" inches tall and the handle is twisted 3/4" inch square stock. It took me forever to snap a few pics of these.
 
Since I am posting old work, here is a photograph of a Japanese style tanto blade I made. The shape was made famous by one of Japan's early and very famous smiths, Masamune. It came out alright, but after I polished it up I discovered two tiny cracks that had formed during the water-quenching process. It's been laying around since I discovered those, but I think I'll cut it up and make a smaller knife out of it.  Oh, in its current state, I suppose its about 11" inches long.
http://ibis-news.livejournal.com/953.html

Well, I've just reopened my antiques business after a hiatus of two years, during which I've more or less been focused on learning bladesmithing skills and techniques from a really talented full time maker living here in north fla.
Its been a little stressful getting back into the swing of things, and I'm not completely there yet. For now my plan is to sell on ebay, with the possibility of moving to an online catalogue. A model I admire is that of Artzi, a dealer in Israel, at www.oriental-arms.com
Initially when getting back into this, my biggest fear was "How am I going to keep up a steady flow of inventory?"  For the past month I've been testing different methods, and while I enjoy traveling to different shows searching for items, my best luck has been with purchasing goods online. Things that people know less about than I do, and so they don't market them properly to reach the correct demographic. When I can intuit how someone might poorly advertise a good item, either because they don't know or because their knowledge is flawed or incomplete, I'll buy that item and in turn correctly advertise it to the people who want it the most.
My business cards read that I specialize in "antiques, oriental art, and edged weapons."  Since this is in large part a game of knowledge, I can only confidently work with the things I know the most about. So far, that translates to Asian porcelains and historical swords and related weapons. It is in the latter of these two areas that I'm getting interested in doing limited specialized conservation and restoration work. 
I hope to here post pictures of some of the antiques I'm working with.

I've been learning to make knives from Jesse Frank, an immensely talented and generous artist, bladesmith, teacher, and friend whose focus since before I met him has been early Scandinavian styled blades based on historical examples. When I first met him I hadn't even used an angle grinder and the idea of making swords for a living seemed like a lovely fantasy.  It's been two years since then, and in that time my knowledge of tools and techniques has grown immensely. Making swords for a living is no longer a fantasy, but a very real path. A difficult path that few will take, but more rewarding and truth revealing than any other I've been exposed to. 

Here is a piece I just picked up. Chinese porcelain hat ornament with five-clawed dragon. Well modeled and levigated porcelainous body glazed to resemble jade. Only three inches long. Compare with a 19th century ruyi scepter similar in decoration and glaze sold at Sotheby's NY, March 19th 1997, lot #292 in the sale "Fine Chinese Ceramics, Furniture, and Works of Art"
As a side note I paid less than $20 for this piece. It was apparently collected by a traveling missionary nun in the early part of the previous century.
